definitions.definition: A store or supply .

subdefinitions.definition: ( operations ) A store of goods ready for sale; inventory .
examples: We have a stock of televisions on hand.
I checked in the back of the stockroom and found some more stock .

subdefinitions.definition: A supply of anything, stored until used; especially, such a supply that is ready for use.
examples: Lay in a stock of wood for the winter season.

subdefinitions.definition: Railroad rolling stock .
examples: The Grand Trunk Railway had just purchased a large order of stock from the American Car and Foundry Company.

subdefinitions.definition: ( card games , in a card game ) A stack of undealt cards made available to the players.
Farm or ranch animals; livestock .
examples: Good ranchers must continually keep watch over the health of their stock .

subdefinitions.definition: The population of a given type of animal (especially fish) available to be captured from the wild for economic use.
examples: The stocks of this fishery are recovering from overfishing, but the gains can easily reverse if our husbandry efforts lapse.

definitions.definition: ( finance ) The capital raised by a company through the issue of shares ; the total of shares held by an individual shareholder.
examples: His grandpa had bought some stock in General Electric in 1905, and he refused to sell it ever after.

subdefinitions.definition: The price or value of the stock of a company on the stock market .
examples: When the bad news came out, the company's stock dropped precipitously.

subdefinitions.definition: ( especially US ) A share in a company.
( figurative ) The measure of how highly a person or institution is valued.
examples: After that last screw-up of mine, my stock is pretty low around here.

subdefinitions.definition: Any of several types of security that are similar to a stock, or marketed like one.

definitions.definition: The raw material from which things are made, such as feedstock .

subdefinitions.definition: ( cooking , uncountable , countable ) Broth made from meat (originally bones) or vegetables, used as a basis for stew or soup .
examples: They make beef stock from the butchery scraps that they otherwise might not have used.

subdefinitions.definition: The type of paper used in printing.
examples: The books were printed on a heavier stock this year.

subdefinitions.definition: Ellipsis of film stock .
Plain soap before it is coloured and perfumed.

definitions.definition: Stock theater , summer stock theater .
The trunk and woody main stems or limbs of a tree; the base from which something grows or branches .

subdefinitions.definition: ( horticulture ) The plant upon which the scion is grafted .
( by extension ) Lineage ; family ; ancestry . ( linguistics ) A larger grouping of language families: a superfamily or macrofamily .

definitions.definition: Any of the several species of cruciferous flowers in the genus Matthiola .
A handle or stem to which the working part of an implement or weapon is attached .

subdefinitions.definition: ( firearms ) The part of a rifle or shotgun that rests against the shooter's shoulder .
The handle of a whip , fishing rod , etc.

definitions.definition: Part of a machine that supports items or holds them in place.

subdefinitions.definition: The headstock of a lathe , drill , etc.
The tailstock of a lathe .

definitions.definition: A bar , stick , or rod .

subdefinitions.definition: A ski pole .
( nautical ) A bar going through an anchor , perpendicular to the flukes .
( nautical ) The axle attached to the rudder , which transfers the movement of the helm to the rudder.
( geology ) A pipe (vertical cylinder of ore)

definitions.definition: A type of (now formal or official) neckwear .

subdefinitions.definition: A necktie or cravat , particularly a wide necktie popular in the eighteenth century, often seen today as a part of formal wear for horse riding competitions.
A piece of black cloth worn under a clerical collar .

definitions.definition: A bed for infants ; a crib , cot , or cradle
( folklore ) A piece of wood magically made to be just like a real baby and substituted for it by magical beings.
( obsolete ) A cover for the legs; a stocking .
A block of wood; something fixed and solid; a pillar; a firm support; a post.
( by extension , obsolete ) A person who is as dull and lifeless as a stock or post; one who has little sense.

( UK , historical ) The longest part of a split tally stick formerly struck in the exchequer , which was delivered to the person who had lent the king money on account, as the evidence of indebtedness.
( shipbuilding , in the plural ) The frame or timbers on which a ship rests during construction.
( UK , in the plural ) Red and grey bricks, used for the exterior of walls and the front of buildings.
( biology ) In tectology , an aggregate or colony of individuals , such as trees, chains of salpae , etc.
The beater of a fulling mill .

definitions.definition: A thrust with a rapier ; a stoccado .

main_definition: A thrust with a rapier ; a stoccado .
